page.title: 03ENVIRONMENT
page.content: TRAQUAIR VILLAGE IS SET NEAR THE CONFLUENCE OF THE QUAIR, A TROUTSTREAM, AND SALMON RIVER, THE TWEED. THE FARMLAND AROUND THE VILLAGE IS DIVIDED BY STONE DYKES WITH SOME HAWTHORN HEDGES AND BY SMALL BURNS RUNNING INTO THE QUAIR, THE LATTER LINED WITH TREES, NOTABLY ALDER, SALLOW, WILLOW AND ASH. PLANTED WOODS INCLUDE MATURE SCOTS PINE, DOUGLAS FIR, NORWAY SPRUCE, LARCH AND SILVER BIRCH, BUT NATIVE BROADLEAVED TREES SUCH AS OAK, BEECH, ROWAN, HOLLY, WYCH ELM AND WILD CHERRY OCCUR IN THE MARGINS AND AS OCCASIONALS. THE GROUNDS OF TRAQUAIR HOUSE HAVE BEEN WELL PLANTED. RHODODENDRON, YEW, WESTERN HEMLOCK, WESTERN RED CEDAR, BOX AND COPPER BEECH FORM DENSE WOODLAND, WITH TURKEY OAK AND BOTH SWEET AND HORSE CHESTNUTS PRESENT IN THE MAIN AVENUE.
